claim: After joining a Facebook group, you learned that essential oils cure cancer.

supporting.text: There is no scientific evidence from clinical trials that essential oils can cure cancer.

attacks.text: There is no scientific evidence from clinical trials that essential oils can cure cancer.
Some anecdotal reports and testimonials suggest that essential oils have helped cancer patients.
Anecdotal evidence lacks scientific rigor and may be influenced by placebo effects or other factors.
Certain essential oils have shown anti-cancer properties in laboratory studies.
Laboratory studies do not equate to clinical effectiveness in humans, and many promising compounds fail in trials.

supporting.text: The FDA has not approved any essential oils for the treatment or cure of cancer.

attacks.text: The FDA has not approved any essential oils for the treatment or cure of cancer.
FDA approval is not the only measure of efficacy; many alternative treatments work without formal approval.
Lack of FDA approval often indicates insufficient clinical evidence or safety concerns, making unapproved treatments risky.
Essential oils have been used in traditional medicine for centuries with anecdotal success in treating various ailments.
Anecdotal evidence lacks scientific rigor and may be influenced by placebo effects or other biases.

supporting.text: Cancer is a complex disease that requires medical treatment such as chemotherapy, radiation, or surgery, not alternative therapies like essential oils.

attacks.text: Cancer is a complex disease that requires medical treatment such as chemotherapy, radiation, or surgery, not alternative therapies like essential oils.
Some studies suggest that certain essential oils have anti-cancer properties in laboratory settings, though clinical evidence is limited.
Laboratory results do not necessarily translate to effective human treatments, and essential oils lack rigorous clinical trials for cancer treatment.
Alternative therapies like essential oils can complement conventional treatments by alleviating side effects such as nausea or stress.
While complementary therapies may improve quality of life, they should not be promoted as cures for cancer, as this could discourage patients from seeking proven treatments.

supporting.text: Mainstream medical organizations, such as the American Cancer Society, do not endorse essential oils as a cure for cancer.

attacks.text: Mainstream medical organizations, such as the American Cancer Society, do not endorse essential oils as a cure for cancer.
Some alternative medicine practitioners and anecdotal reports claim success with essential oils in treating cancer symptoms.
Anecdotal reports lack scientific rigor and are often subject to placebo effects or misattribution of outcomes.
Essential oils may have palliative effects, such as reducing stress or nausea, which can indirectly support cancer patients.
Palliative effects are not equivalent to curing cancer, and conflating the two is misleading.

supporting.text: Essential oils may have therapeutic benefits for symptoms like nausea or stress, but they do not address the underlying causes of cancer.

attacks.text: Essential oils may have therapeutic benefits for symptoms like nausea or stress, but they do not address the underlying causes of cancer.
Some essential oils, like frankincense, have shown anti-cancer properties in laboratory studies.
Laboratory studies do not necessarily translate to effective cancer treatments in humans.
Essential oils can improve quality of life for cancer patients, which indirectly supports healing.
Quality of life improvements are not equivalent to curing cancer.

supporting.text: Relying on essential oils instead of proven medical treatments can delay effective care and worsen cancer outcomes.

attacks.text: Relying on essential oils instead of proven medical treatments can delay effective care and worsen cancer outcomes.
Some essential oils have shown anti-cancer properties in preliminary lab studies, suggesting potential benefits.
Lab studies do not equate to clinical efficacy, and no essential oil has been proven to cure cancer in humans.
Alternative treatments like essential oils can complement conventional medicine without replacing it.
Patients may misinterpret 'complementary' as 'substitutive,' leading to dangerous delays in evidence-based care.
